text:
So as Joe said, I
had the huge fortune while I was in the
Air Force to come here

to do graduate research on the
effect of government funding on new technology, venture
creation and growth, which

at the time, when I started,
I had no idea what that meant. And I took this class
by this great professor

coming from the Air
Force, and going like, How do big organizations innovate? That was going to be my thesis. And I took one class
with Ernestine.

And I said, I'm not doing
that anymore, threw that to the side. I'm going to work with startups
and work with founders. I'm going to work with the
bleeding edge of innovation

because I think that's
where, for me personally, the most interest was. And it certainly changed
my entire career.

And it kind of led us to
give us the opportunity to stand up this office,
which has really been

a big push by the Department. So I've got a couple of slides. I'll walk through a bit
about who we are, what we do,

what our focus is,
but then very keenly interested in your questions. I think Ernestine
is going to come up, and we'll have a
chat after this.

So the Office of Strategic
Capital, as Joe mentioned, it exists to attract and scale
private capital and support

of national security. Why? Because, as Joe
also mentioned, we are in a global
competition for emerging

and critical technologies. When we say "critical
technologies,"

the US government has a really
diverse set of technology areas that they think are
critical, critical for

national and economic security. These represent key industries. In the Department of Defense,
we have 14 critical technology

areas. Some of them are very much
military focused-- hypersonics, directed energy.

But many of them
are what I consider pervasive enabling industries.

Semiconductors is a
great example of this. Every government department
in the United States-- we've got a varied set of
departments and agencies

that focus on some
aspect of technology-- has semiconductors as a
critical enabling technology.

Renewable energy,
biotech, quantum, advanced materials-- these
are all critical industries

for the future of US
competitive advantage. Now, in fueling
these industries,

in fueling the continued
innovation, growth, scale-up, manufacturing, production of the
technologies and products that

are derived from
those technologies, it is private capital that
is the dominant source of financing.

So a US policy
generally-- and this has kind of been this
way since World War II.

The US government
policy is, we are going to fund the
advancement of basic research through prototyping action.

We had a $184-billion budget
last year that focused on this aspect of technology creation
and the initial stages of what

we would call productization,
which basically takes something from an a concept
to a prototype.

But it's the private
capital markets that are responsible for
driving the commercialization, or going from prototype
to product, and then

from product to scale, to pay
for infrastructure, production, and manufacturing.

Now, in this
competitive framework, if we know that private
capital is a dominant resource

of financing these
critical technologies, that's a great US
competitive advantage. Why?

Because over half of the
world's private capital is in the United States. We have the largest and
most liquid capital markets. We have the most
sophisticated financial tools.

And they work at very different
areas of the industrial base, in the supply chain, and they
work to motivate returns.

Capital is going
to flow to returns. Again, that's why the US has
the largest and the most liquid capital markets.

The problem that we see today
is that the critical technology areas are not receiving
what we could consider

a sufficient amount of
financing to advance US national economic
security interests, right? So this is just for example.

For example, e-commerce
received nearly 2 and 1/2 times as much investment
as AI over the last few years.

Even if AI's growth
through LLMs, e-commerce is still a
dominant source of financing.

But it's 150 times
more investment than in things like quantum. So if you're working on a PhD in
quantum, and you're like, hey,

I've got this great idea. I want to go
commercialize it-- it's really hard to go find
sources of capital that are willing to fund your company.

Again, why is this is
because software industries or software-enabled industries
can return capital faster.

They're lower
technical risk, right? Investors don't invest
in technology risk. They invest in
business model risk.

They understand that the
technology risk is driven down. So it really is an attempt to
understand product market fit.

And this is a trend that may
be kind of clear to us today but has really kind
of shifted drastically

over the last few
decades, right? So even as close as 2006, '07
time frame when I was doing

my undergrad, 45% of all venture
investment was in hardware. Back in 2017, closer to 8%.

The last number I saw
was closer to 3%, right? We've seen a massive
decline of early stage

commercial investment in
hardware-based enabled industries.

There's lots of very good
reasons for this from a capital market perspective, right? Hardware industries
are more expensive.

They're more
capital-intensive industries. They take longer to
generate a return, and they're normally in fields
that are less well understood

and can be less well
priced by investors, right? If I'm investing in
fintech companies,

I could do eight deals
at $5 million a pop. And I kind of know what the
return profiles look like. And I know what
my net margins are

going to look like because
there's comparables out there. If I'm doing work in
metamaterials, right-- there's, like, one IPO
in the last three years

at $260-million
valuation, right? It is not looked at as a
returnable venture-style

investment. And so what we see is
all of these technologies that we, the Department
of Defense, who represents

over half of the
country's R&D budget, or our colleagues at the
National Science Foundation or the Department of Energy,
are financing or building

these great prototypes--
and there's just not access to capital to advance those
technologies from where they

are in their development
from prototype into a commercial
product, right? There isn't a market,
an investment market,

or a capital market for those
types or those industries that we think are critical to
national economic security.

And so the national
security strategy has taken a hard look at how do
we increase capital investments

in these areas. So in the national
security strategy, it says, "We must complement
the innovative power

of the private sector with a
modern industrial strategy that makes strategic public
investments in America's

workforce, in strategic sectors,
and supply chains, especially critical in emerging
technologies, such as microelectronics,
advanced computing,

biotechnologies, clean
energy technologies, and advanced
telecommunications." And you've seen this
over the last few years

in things like the
CHIPS Act, which provided a significant amount of
financing into semiconductors.

Why? Because we're trying to crowd
in-- this concept of crowding in, attracting private capital-- into areas that it otherwise is
not attracted to investing in.

Jake Sullivan kind of
reiterates this that today, from a national
security perspective, we're investing in
industries of the future,

strengthening the resilience and
security of the supply chains that underpin them. With each of these
investments, our goal is to 'crowd in'
private capital,

not replace it, and
attract 'patient capital' to bring these critical
technologies to scale. You'll hear us talk about this
concept of patient capital.

What is patient capital? Patient capital
is capital that is OK with taking longer
timelines to return.

That's all it is. So it's saying, hey, instead
of doing a traditional 5- to 7- or 7- to 10-year fund--

it may take a space
space company 14 years to generate profitability. Qualcomm is a great
example of this.

Qualcomm defined an
entire technology area funded by programs
like the Small Business

Innovative Research,
SBIR, program-- went on for massive success
but took a long time to generate return and
profitability to its earlier

investors. And so I'm going to go
back in time a little bit, and there's a lot of young faces
here, so I'll pose a question.
Who knows what this is? And I'll give you a hint. It's on the slide. [INAUDIBLE]

So it's the Cray-1
supercomputer. This is the world's
first supercomputer Cray Research founded
in the early 1970s--

was struggling, like a lot
of deep tech companies, to raise capital to produce the
world's first supercomputer.

into a recession. Investors are
starting to move away from investing in
deep tech companies.

This is just past the
era of Intel investment and semiconductor
companies really--

the industry really
being birthed. And now capital is
starting to dry up. And it's drying up mostly in
the areas of the economy that

are the most expensive to invest
in, like building a brand-new product for a market
that does not exist. Now, fortunately for Cray,
there was this program

at the time called the Small
Business Investment Company program, SBIC program. Show of hands, who
knows what SBIR is?

OK, who knows what SBIC is? So SBICs are the much
older sibling of SBIR.

Eisenhower administration
goes, jeez, we got to do something
about this technology race.

So Eisenhower administration
does three massive things. They create this organization
called DARPA, they create NASA,

and they create the Small
Business Investment Company program, SBIC program. And the SBIC program provides
government-backed loans

to equity investors
to make investments in areas of national
security concern. The SBIC program helps
to massively accelerate

this brand-new asset class
called venture capital. At one point in the mid-1960s,

are backed by the US government
through the SBIC program. It funds companies like Intel,
like Sun, like Apple computing,

like the Cray supercomputer. And now, this program provided
a lot of very necessary capital,

especially when markets are
heading to reduce spending and capital
intensive industries, because for receipt of
this low cost of financing,

government-backed loans,
the equity investors have to make investments in areas
that the country thinks are important.

So John F. Carlson, who's
the CFO of Cray Research, talks about how critical
this program was for Cray.

"The role of the SBIC program
in securing continuation capital for Cray Research in 1975
cannot be overemphasized.

Some may claim that if the
SBIC had not been there, Cray would have
found another way. Our venture capitalists
tell us otherwise.

Cray was a company
with no product, slipping schedules, and
no serious prospects, facing a market
generally thought

to be no bigger than and competing with
well-funded and established competing programs.

Furthermore, the capital
market was sluggish. Into this environment
the taxpayers invested"-- word I'll go back to-- less
than $500,000 and became

the stimulus for
investment of $2.3 million, enough to save Cray Research."

So through the SBIC
program, the taxpayers provided loans to
investors that crowded in additional private
capital that saved Cray.

But this word "invested"
that I want to highlight, because if you worked
in the DOD, you know we use this term "invested"
all of the time.

We have investment
dollars, right? DOD doesn't invest any money. We spend money, right? We have $184 billion to spend.

We don't get any of
that back, right? The SBIC program is
government-backed loans.

There is no money spent
through this program. It is lent. Of note, the SBIC
program still exists.

It's been around since 1958. And in the last nearly been no taxpayer dollars--
no appropriated dollars

have gone to the program. And it's mobilized billions
of dollars of capital. Now it's moved
away from investing

in critical technology
areas, but I'll circle back to that in a little bit. So having gone to
Stanford-- and I've

tons of business school
people in our office. I have to start or kind
of go into a two-by-two.

So at OSC, we operate
on a framework we call the critical
technologies framework.

And we think about this in
terms of two primary dimensions. We're thinking about
technology competition.

It's about advancing
technologies into industries, industries
being where a technology

company can produce a
product, make a return, sell the product to a market,
and generate profitability,

right? So we want to see this kind
of virtuous cycle of growth happening in these key
enabling industries.

Typically, in an
government R&D hat, you're thinking about
advancing technology and maybe

manufacturing across this
thing called a TRL, Technology Readiness Level. Who knows what a TRL is?

Great. So technology readiness
levels-- basically, it's just a measure of going from
basic research, a white paper,

into a fully fledged
product, let's say, that's open and
available to the market. So typically, we think
across this x-axis,

going from early-stage
technologies to later-stage technologies. We've matured technologies
over this thing called

the "valley of death," right? But at OSC, we also think
about the supply chain.

And we think about this
because the DOD primarily funds things called
capabilities, right?

So the Department
of Defense is going to fund things for the
Air Force, the Space Force, the Navy, the Army.

Those are all important to
the Department of Defense. But where it doesn't
fund directly

after this S&T side of the house
again, after this $184 billion of financing, is things
in our supply chain.

We call these
component technologies. Again, this circles back to
semiconductors and things like biofuels and
advanced materials.

And so we today, and have
done over the last few years, have done a significant
survey of government programs

that focus on DOD or national
security critical technology areas. And our position
on this is that we

don't have formal programs
that focus on these technology areas that are inherently within
our industrial base today,

with some notable exceptions,
like the CHIPS and Science Act, like the work that the DOE
Loan Program Office is doing.

And so we've identified that
these are strategic capital needs in the commercialization
stages of these technology

areas and the growth stages
of these technology areas. So I know at Stanford, we think
a lot about venture capital.

But at OSC, we're thinking about
the entire capital continuum, all the way from
commercialization

through manufacturing
and infrastructure. How do we increase the
capacity and production quality

and quantity within
these industries and do it in a way that supports
national and economic security?

So our first program
that we launched was a Small Business Investment
Companies Critical Technologies Initiative, which is a
program that's available today

own the SBIC program
and created a program initiative around
critical technology areas.

So investors today are applying
to be part of the SBIC program. And the way it works, if
you're unfamiliar with--

show of hands. Who knows what this
concept of leverage is? Leveraged finance. Awesome, OK.

So most of you do,
which is great.

Leveraged finance is the
application of debt to equity

to shift the return
profiles, right? You're leveraging the returns. It's commonly used
in private equity.

It was used in venture,
not so much today. But how this works
is the US government

provides government-backed
loans that partner with private capital. So investors have to bring their
own money to the table, which

can be matched
through this program with government-backed loans. What this does is it
creates an investment fund,

a licensed limited
partnership that then has the mandate to
invest in critical technology

companies. It's a very simple process. But effectively, what
it does is it allows you to take $1 of private
capital and allocate $2 to $3

into the ecosystem, into
companies themselves, as equity investment. Now, all the returns
and profitability

above repaying the
government-backed loan goes back to the general partner
in the limited partnership,

right? Why is this such a useful tool? And why did we use it
during, some would say,

the last great
power competition? We use it because it allows us
to scalably attract and scale

private capital, scalably
attract and scale private capital because
it does it in a way

that it doesn't cost the
taxpayer any money, right? The intent of these programs
are to be to low to no costs,

right? As we talked about,
the SBA program-- again, been running since 1958--
over the last few decades,

has not cost
taxpayers any money. It's a very different
program than typical defense-based programs,
which are very much focused

on contracts and
grants, allocating money to advanced technologies. This is the next stage. How do we reduce government
spending and do it in a way

where we can increase
private capital allocation into the areas that
we think are most important to national
security, but do it in a way where they are
generating enough of a return

to repay the debt? That's the whole
generalized concept of OSC is how do we work with
investors, work with companies,

to increase private capital
investment in those areas that we think are most
important to national security. As I said, applications
are open right now.

So tell your favorite VC
or private equity fund to go and apply for the program.

And very excited to
take your questions. Thank you for time.

[APPLAUSE] So, Jason, thanks for
providing that context.

Definitely have a number
of questions on OSC and the incredible
work you've definitely been busy this past year.

But maybe we can start off with
just some context in terms of, you went to MIT, joined the
Air Force, Stanford PhD,

and then launched Venture
as part of AFWERX. What inspired you
to leave that role?

And why did you feel
the need to launch OSC? Well, like I said
in the beginning,

your class really inspired me
to think differently about-- And to learn how to spell. --and learn how to, spell
which, as an MIT grad,

I still don't really
know how to spell. But the venture
capital, I think,

having been in a
part of the last-- the global war on
terror and understanding

what the Department
was doing at that time and really trying to understand
how do we drive the best

tech into our Air Force gave
us really a new vertical

that we've been growing
inside of the Department. How do we bring in young
companies, entrepreneurs,

startups who want to work with
the Department of Defense? And our goal when we
built AFWERX and we built AFVentures, which was like the
SBIR funding arm of AFWERX,

was I want every series A
company, every seed company, to take a look at the Air
Force as a potential market.

Hey, maybe it's a
good fit for us. Maybe you should come
check us out, right? And we'll do a small grant.

We'll see if there's
a there there. We'll do a technical
feasibility study. And if there is, we'll
continue to increase investment

until we get to the point
where we decide, hey, this is a match. And let's move this from a
prototype into a capability.

But then-- and that program was
growing and growing, growing, and then COVID hit.

And we were asked to come back. I remember I just
had a our first kids.

I think they were maybe
eight, nine days old. And it was like, hey, we got
to come back and move to DC

and help stand up this
COVID task force thing. And that's where I
met JR Gibbens, who

is our chief investment
officer in the back. And we worked on this
concept of understanding,

well, not only what are
the capabilities, right? What are the things,
the products, that we need as a country
in support of the mission?

But also, where do we
have failure points? Because I don't know if
you guys are following COVID, but there was a lot of
supply chain issues, right?

And we were just-- I'm not really tracking the
depth of what those issues are or how those are going
to affect our ability

to acquire things like
PPE or other things that the military needed.

And so we started working on
some of these core concepts. Hey, how do we
get ahead of where we see these supply chain
issues for new and emerging

industries, right? And the DOD is very much
focused on its capabilities and those supply chains. But when we're looking
at new industries,

we're looking at growth
in specific areas, how do we ensure that we
have access to what we need when we need it?

And we saw this as this
monumental problem, right? The N on this has grown--
it grows exponentially

because you're not just
focusing on one capability. You're now focusing on
supply chain, the growth, of the different
industries that comprise

one military
capability is enormous. And so we got to
think, OK, well, we can't just put more
money on the problem.

We can't go ask Congress for
more money to do this, right? Even with COVID-focused
work, we have

to figure out other more
scalable ways to do it. And then we started looking
at our history, right? Were there times in
our history where

we've done this or other
agencies doing this? And DOE has had a loan
program for a long time.

We got to work with them. And then we stumbled across
this great partnership that we have with the SBA.

And at the time-- this
was back in 2020-- a gentleman there,
who's been working there

since the early 1990s, was like,
yeah, we can totally do this. It'll take 18 months to do this.

And we were like, we don't
do things in 18 months. We're AFWERX. We do things in,
like, 30 days, right? This is COVID's now. We got to figure
this problem now.

And ended up taking us,
like, three years to get off the ground, so he was wrong
on the other direction.

But we saw a
massive opportunity. And I think one
thing that this team has continued to do is
try to-- where do we

see gaps that we're just
totally not addressing today? And how do we work to
advance these opportunities

in a way that allows us to get
after the problems in a more unique way? And we're very fortunate to
have the team that we have

because it's really a
lot of the same core team that was kind of
early days in DIU, early days standing up
AFWERX, and now early

days standing this up. Yeah, yeah, so just on that
note of some of these government innovation programs
that you just mentioned, DIU,
In-Q-Tel, DARPA, how

does OSC work with
these existing programs? And how do you also really
differentiate and set yourself

apart? Yeah, so we differentiate
ourselves really in kind of three key ways.

One, we focus on components,
not capabilities, right? We're really focusing on
these primarily commercial,

nonfederal industries, right? Semiconductors. Nobody's going to say
semiconductors are our defense

industrial base, right? They're a technology area
with a diverse and somewhat

hard to navigate at
times supply base where the vast majority of the
revenue for these companies

is coming from
commercial sector. So we focus on components,
not capabilities.

We focus on lending,
not spending, right? We have some
spending-type-focused programs

for integration work. But a lot of our
focus is on lending, which is a very scalable tool
that many other government

departments have used. We've been lending as a country
far longer than we've had a Department of Defense, right? It's a very scalable tool,
used very effectively

over the last many decades. And then we focus on finance,
primarily, not innovation.

So we support the innovation
ecosystem, certainly. And there's a lot
of opportunities that we can help accelerate some
of the core enabling industries

for the innovation ecosystem. But we primarily are
focused on finance, right? How do we work to make
industries investable?

How do we work with
capital markets to increase capital access
for these types of companies?

And then we work with
these other organizations very closely to
see where DARPA--

what's the best greatest
coming out of DARPA? Where are those companies
failing to access capital? Is there focus that we
can put on that area?

Working with organizations
like DRU or AFWERX to understand, OK, what's
the next generation of capabilities that's coming
from the commercial sector that

has good promise
that we can support with advanced materials or
next generation semis or things

like quantum sensing? But try to find areas of
today's capabilities, tomorrow's capabilities, and work in
our industry, support those.

And for these
technologies that you're focused on, these
critical technologies, how do you decide on
which ones to focus on?

And how do you feel like these
priorities will shift over the coming years? It's a really good question.

I would say, there's a diverse
set of government departments, right? So for those of you
who aren't aware d

there's a Department of
Commerce, Department of Energy, the Small Business
Administration, National Science Foundation. They all have kind of their
critical technologies list,

right? And it's kind of like
ours, to be honest. There's a lot of overlap.

But the unique thing that
we do to focus is we say, OK, well, in those
technology areas,

we primarily focus at
macro capital flows. What is the capital? What is the amount of
capital being invested? What's the capital
intensity, right?

How long? What's the mean time to exit
as a company in these areas? which really helps
determine our priority list.

So our priority list
is not necessarily like the priority list
for the country in terms of national security, right?

There's some things that
are going to be on our list or not on our list because of
the opportunity space for where

we see our programs
to be effective, which is primarily of, Where
do we see this partnership opportunity?

Where can the private markets
be incentivized to move? Where can we attract and scale? Where can we be
additive to the market

to increase capital
availability? Some areas, we're
going to offer up. So hopefully, in a
few months, we'll

be able to release
our first investment strategy, which will identify
what our industries are.

And through that
list, those will be a first take to the market. And then the market will
respond, hey, we like these. We can't do these.

That'll tell us
something else about how do we continue to evolve
our analysis over time. Mhm, mhm. And so why do you
think the DOD should

be centered around
providing this sort of loan program versus just becoming
a better buyer of technology?

Another great question. So we don't buy. We don't buy
semiconductors, right? We don't buy
critical components. We don't buy the supply
base for these technologies.

We buy the capabilities. And then providers,
defense tech startups, to defense industrial
base providers,

to companies that are
working across the Department of Defense, are on contract
to provide a thing.

But sometimes we have to ground
the F35 s because the magnets came from China, right? Like, those are
things that happen,

not because of any kind of
negligence, direct negligence, in my opinion. It's because the macro
economy has shifted production

and manufacturing,
has shifted a lot of these technologies, away
from the United States. And that's where
our focus has been

to say, OK, how do we get ahead
of these industries in such a way where we don't need to
have another CHIPS Act, right?

How do we continue to ensure
that these industries are cared for and nurtured in a way
that allow us to ensure that we have secure
access to these components

when we need them? Just given today's
global economy, how do you envision OSC working
with international allies

and investors in
other countries? It is extremely
important that we

continue to work with allies
and partners, many of which have these incredibly useful
tools that we don't have today

in the Department of Defense
or in the US, really. And there's-- like, for
example, out of the UK,

there's the NSSIF, the National
Security Innovation Fund, which is a limited partner to
a lot of funds in the UK that

focus on national security. They have very
different policies around things like lending
or equity investment

than we do in the United States. And then the other
big part of this is-- and in just my personal time,
I've seen over the last,

really, kind of 15 years
a direct realization in a lot of our supporting
strategic documents to say,

you know, critical--
this is going to be a very maybe
a simple statement. But critical technologies are
developed everywhere, right?

Like, the best and brightest
and the latest breakthroughs can be pervasive around
the world, right?

How do we advance those
industries, no matter where they're coming
from, in a way that supports our national
security and economic security

interests? And so working with
allies and partners, working on
comparative advantage, and working on
opportunities for finance

to increase investment in these
areas is extremely important. And is this just for venture
capital providers or--

Full capital stack, right? And so you'll see this-- I mean, the first fund's coming
through the SBICCT Initiative.

Some of them are early
growth-stage-type investors, traditional VCs. Some of them are private
equity, lower, middle,

upper, middle-market-type
investors because the industrial
base is diverse.

Not every company needs
the same type of capital. And they're all different
types of growth. And so we're not trying
to form-fit the function.

But I will just say very
clearly that our partnership with the SBA is a great
learning experience for the Department of Defense.

There's 131 federal
credit programs in the FY24 budget bill.

The DOD is one of three
government departments today that does not execute
a loan program. There's us, Department of Labor,
and Department of Justice.

And so this is a
brand-new thing for us. We've done some work
with other agencies.

We've done some things
through the Defense Production Act, which is a
presidential authority. But this is really a
first-of-its-kind type

of program. And we're really excited
about the opportunity to enter this space. And so we're starting with
SBA and the SBIC program.

And we're going to continue to
evolve our thinking about how these tools can best be applied. Really, really incredible
work that you've been working

on these last several months. So what are the goals for, say,
